loans.name: Sop Mame Awa Balla Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Sop Mame Awa Balla du Banc Villageois Sop Borom Darou Mousty est créé depuis le 10 décembre 2010,il est composé de dix sept femmes qui sont toutes parentes et le petit commerce (d'habits,parfums,bijoux) est leur activité principale; elles font aussi de l'élevage.

Madame Coumba la responsable est âgée de 41 ans, elle es mariée sans enfant mais a en charge ses trois nièces et un neveu;elle mène comme activité principale l'embouche ovine et a une bonne expérience. Sur la photo elle est debout à droite et est habillée en bleu.

Elle achète ses moutons dans les marchés hebdomadaires, les élèvent et les revend à l'approche du recouvrement.

Son prêt lui permettra d'acheter des moutons pour l'embouche et des aliments de bétail.

Ses bénéfices lui permettent de renforcer son épargne et d'aider son mari pour le bien être de la famille.
texts.en:
The Sop Mama Awa Balla community group from the Sop Borome Darou Mousty village bank was formed on the 10th December 2010. The group is made up of seventeen women who are all related, and whose main line of trade is in clothes, perfume and jewellery. They are also involved in the rearing of animals. 

Madame Coumba is the group leader and is 41 years old and married. She has no children of her own, but looks after her three nieces and one nephew. Her main line of trade is in rearing animals, where she has considerable experience. She is standing on the right hand side in the photo, wearing blue. 

She buys her sheep from the weekly market, rears them and then sells them on.  This loan will enable her to purchase sheep for rearing, and cattle feed. The profits she generates will enable her to boost her savings and help her husband to see to the family's well-being.

loans.use: to purchase sheep for rearing and sale

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Mrs. Pen, 27, lives in the province of Siem Reap and cares for one child. She runs a small wooden store in front of her house, where she sells little snack foods, soft drinks, shampoo, and some groceries to her neighbors. 

To generate more income, her husband works as a motor taxi driver in and around his village. Mrs. Pen is requesting her loan to buy grocery inventory for her store. She will use the rest of the money to buy a new motor for her husband to run his motor taxi service.

loans.use: to buy grocery inventory for her store and to buy a new motor for her husband's taxi

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to prepare a women-only section of her internet cafe.

loans.name: Sop Borom Darou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Sop Borom Darou du Banc Villageois Sop Borom Darou Mousty est créé depuis le 10 décembre 2010;il est composé de dix huit femmes qui habitent toutes le même quartier et font du petit commerce de produits divers:habits,parfums,draps de lits,bijoux etc....

La responsable madame Adji âgée de 39 ans est mariée sans enfant mais a deux en charge, elle s'active dans le petit commerce d'arachide de chaussures, bijoux, habits enfants et femmes. Elle est à droite sur la photo est habillée en boubou bleu blanc.


Elle achéte ses marchandises dans les grandes villes et revend dans son quartier.

Son prêt lui permettra de renforcer son activité.


Elle appui son mari dans la gestion des dépenses familiales avec les bénéfices obtenus mais renforce aussi son épargne.
texts.en:
The Sop Borom Darou solidarity group of the Sop Borom Darou Mousty was formed on the 10th December 2010. It is made up of eighteen women who all live in the same quarter and sell various items for a living, e.g. clothes, perfume, bedsheets, jewellery etc. 

The group leader, madame Adji, is 39 years old and married. She has no children of her own, but has two in her care. She sells peanuts, shoes, jewellery and clothing for women and children. She is on the right hand side of the photo, wearing a blue and white boubou (robe). 

She buys her goods from the nearest large town and re-sells them in her quarter. This loan will enable her to boost her business levels. 

With the profits she generates from the business she supports her husband in meeting the family's needs, and also puts some money aside for savings.

loans.use: to purchase shoes, clothes, jewellery and peanuts

loans.name: Noupagagnon Iv Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe NOUPAGAGNON IV sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans, 3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à  TAMBA, un des villages de la commune de NANTIEN dans la préfecture de SIKASSO, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
Les spéculations cultivées sont : l’arachide et le pois sucré avec NADIARA 2ème accroupie à gauche de la photo.
 Avec son prêt, elle compte payer les frais de labour, acheter des intrants et les semences pour entretenir : 0.5hectare. 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village et au marché de SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 12.500FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
Elle souhaite entretenir  cette collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’ exploiter au mieux son espace cultural pour en tirer plus de gains.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Noupagagnon IV group are all married women who are on average 36 years old with three children.  They mostly live in polygamous families in Tamba, one of the villages in the Nantien commune in the Sikasso municipality, the third largest region in the Republic of Mali. They are working with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance collective in order to boost their agricultural activities during the off-season. 
They are on their fifth loan with the organisation, and all previous loans have been repaid. 
The women, led by Nadiara (the second person kneeling on the left in the photo) cultivate peanuts and sweet peas. With this loan, she aims to pay for labour costs, and to purchase fertilisers etc and seeds for a 0.5 hectare plot of land. 
After harvesting, the crops are sold in the village and at the Sikasso market to a customer base made up of men and women. Nadiara aims to generate an average monthly profit of 12,500 FCFA. 
This profit will enable her to repay her loan as well as supporting her husband with the family's everyday needs. She wishes to maintain this relationship with Soro Yiriwaso so that she can make the most of her plot of land, and generate greater profits from it.

loans.use: to pay labour costs and to purchase agricultural inputs (eg fertilisers) and seeds

loans.name: Matanat

texts.ru: Matanat 32 qoda. Ona zamujem i imeyet odnogo rebonka. Matanat jivet v Baku regione vmeste so svoyey semyoy. Ona uje 5 let kak rabotayet v konsaltingovom biznesse. Seychas ona nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit noviy kompyuter dlya predostavleniya svoim kliyentam ludshego obslujivaniya. Etomu biznessu ona nauchilas u svoyego druga kotoriy pomog yey v etom biznesse.
texts.en: Matanat is 32 years old.  SHe is married and has one child.  Matanat lives in Baku with her family.  She has worked in consulting for five years.  Now she needs 2000 AZN to buy a new computer to provide her clients with better service.  She started this business with her friend who helped her with it.

loans.use: to buy a new computer

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is 40 years old, married to Victoria and has four school-aged children. He has practised farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 16 years. He was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by one of our field officers and this will be his third loan. He has paid all his previous loans well and in good time. Simon plans to use the loan amount to buy more sheep, which he will rear and later sell the wool.
In the future, Simon hopes to buy more sheep, which he will rear and also be able to sell the newborns.

loans.use: to buy more sheep for rearing.

loans.name: Nguitte Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 19 mai 2007. Il est  constitué de treize femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame Pauline qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main et le responsable de groupe. Elle est âgée de 49 ans. Elle est veuve et mère de trois enfants. Elle a aussi en sa charge un autre enfant confié par un parent.

Elle s’active dans la vente de légume et de fruit. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité, car étant pratiquer depuis plusieurs années.

Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités.
Les profits lui permettront d’améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille (scolarité etc.…)
texts.en:
This solidarity group was formed on May 19, 2007.  It is made up of 13 women, all living in the same neighborhood.  Their main business is small-scale sales.
Pauline, who is raising her hand at right in the photo, is the group leader.  She is 49 years old, and a widowed mother of three.  She also has one additional child entrusted to her care by a relative.
She works selling fruits and vegetables.  She has considerable experience in this field, having worked in it for several years.
This loan will enable her to increase her operating funds and to expand her business.   The profits will enable her to improve her family’s living conditions (cost of education, etc.).

loans.use: to purchase fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Ngetere Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 19 mai 2007. Il est  constitué de treize femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce et le maraichage.

Madame Antoinette qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main est responsable de groupe. Elle est âgée de 45 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de trois enfants. 

Elle s’active dans la vente de légumes. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité, car étant pratiquer depuis plusieurs années.

Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités.
Les profits lui permettront de participer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de la famille (la nourriture, la santé etc.…)
texts.en:
This solidarity group was formed on May 19, 2007.  It is made up of 13 women, all living in the same neighborhood.  Their main business is small-scale sales and farming.

Antoinette, who is raising her hand at right in the photo, is the group leader.  She is 45 years old and a married mother of three.  

She works selling vegetables.  She has considerable experience in this field, having worked in it for several years.

This loan will enable her to increase her operating funds and to expand her business.   The profits will enable her to help improve her family’s living conditions (food, healthcare costs, etc.).

loans.use: to purchase vegetables

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is 28 years old, married, and has two children aged one and five. He runs a furniture-making shop at Kambi in Kakamega. Peter has been running his business for four years now and has one employee. He hopes to use his loan to purchase timber to further develop his furniture-making shop. He also hopes that in future, he will be able to purchase a vehicle for use in his business. He describes himself as a visionary man.

loans.use: to purchase timber.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan is an aggressive 25-year-old businesswoman. She is married and blessed with two children. She has been running a cosmetics shop since 2002. She is grateful to Kiva partner, Faulu Kenya, for making funds available to her. This has helped her to boost her business. In the next five years, she wants to have opened several business outlets. Her dream is to gain a wider market for her products.
Joan wants a loan of 50,000 Kenyan Shillings to buy cosmetics products and repaint her business premises.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics and repaint her business premises.

loans.name: Natioub Kafane Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 19 mai 2007. Il est  constitué de treize femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce et le maraichage.

Madame Brigitte Bienvenue qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main est responsable de groupe. Elle est âgée de 32 ans. Elle est célibataire et mère de deux enfants. 

Elle s’active dans la vente de légumes. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité, pour l'avoir pratiquer depuis plusieurs années.

Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités.

Les profits lui permettront d’améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille (santé, nourriture, habillement etc.…)
texts.en:
This solidarity group was formed on May 19, 2007.  It is made up of 13 women, all living in the same neighborhood.  Their main business is small-scale sales and farming.

Brigitte Bienvenue, who is raising her hand at right in the photo, is the group leader.  She is 32 years old and a single mother of two. 
 
She works selling vegetables.  She has considerable experience in this field, having worked in it for several years.

This loan will enable her to increase her operating funds and to expand her business.   

The profits will enable her to improve her family’s living conditions (healthcare, food, clothing, etc.).

loans.use: to purchase vegetables

loans.name: Noupagagnon V Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe NOUPAGAGNON V sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 37ans, 3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à  TAMBA, un des villages de la commune de NANTIEN dans la préfecture de SIKASSO, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
Les spéculations cultivées sont : l’arachide et le pois sucré avec SOUCKO 1ère à droite position debout de la photo.
 Avec son prêt, elle compte payer les frais de labour, acheter des intrants et les semences pour entretenir : 0.5 hectare. 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village et au marché de SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40.500FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
Elle souhaite entretenir  cette collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’ exploiter au mieux son espace cultural pour en tirer plus de gains.
texts.en:
The six members of the Noupagagnon V group are married women averaging 37 years of age with three children and living mostly in polygamous families in Tamba, a village in the commune of Nantien, Sikasso Prefecture, the third administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better manage their agricultural activities during the rainy season.

They are on their fifth loan with the institution, and their prior loans have been duly repaid.

They cultivate peanuts [ground nuts] and sweet peas, which is, for example, what Soucko does (she is the first one standing on the right in the photo). With her loan, she plans to pay labor costs, buy agricultural inputs [fertilizers etc] and seeds in order to work a land plot of 0.5 ha [1.2 acres].

After harvesting, the produce is sold at the village and at the Sikasso market to a customer base composed of both men and women.

She plans to earn an average income of 40,500 West African Francs per agricultural season. This income will allow her to repay her loan and help her husband provide for everyday household expenses. She would like to continue  collaborating with Soro Yiriwaso in order to cultivate her land better and derive a bigger income from it.

loans.use: to pay for manual labor and buy seeds, fertilizers etc.

loans.name: Lisungi Plus Group

texts.en:
Charlotte is the leader of the Community Bank named “Lisungi Plus”, which is composed of 15 members united in solidarity to receive Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses.
Charlotte is 46 years old, a widow and the mother of ten children, whose ages range between 9 and 28 years old. Six of her children attend school. Charlotte has been part of the micro-enterprise world since 2007. She operates a general store and sells prepaid cards in the mid-west of Kinshasa. She works hard and employs good management skills in order to realize her dream of someday becoming a main provider in her environment. She would also like to achieve financial independence through her business, which currently earns her $100 per week. Charlotte has already obtained and correctly repaid 11 loans from microfinance institution and Kiva partner, HOPE DRC. She will increase her stock of merchandise with her next loan by buying one sack of flour, one sack of sugar, vegetable oil and some prepaid cards in bulk to resell at a profit.

loans.use: to increase her store’s stock by buying one sack of flour, one sack of sugar, vegetable oil and some prepaid cards in bulk for reselling at profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
This is Yolanda, a 47-year-old mother and resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Edward, a laborer. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Yolanda operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families only eat home-cooked meals in the evening, when all of the family members are at home to partake of the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food on one or two people, when buying prepared rice and viands costs less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 1,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 30,000-PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more products like meat, rice, vegetables, condiments, and seasonings. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Yolanda dreams of being able to give all her children a high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her fellowship co-members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

 * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw ingredients she needs in her business

loans.name: Noupagagnon Vi Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe NOUPAGAGNON VI sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans, 3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à  TAMBA, un des villages de la commune de NANTIEN dans la préfecture de SIKASSO, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
Les spéculations cultivées sont : l’arachide et le pois sucré avec SAFIATOU 1ère à droite position debout de la photo.
 Avec son prêt, elle compte payer les frais de labour, acheter des intrants et les semences pour entretenir : 0.5 hectare. 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village et au marché de SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 30.000FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
Elle souhaite entretenir  cette collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’ exploiter au mieux son espace cultural pour en tirer plus de gains.
texts.en:
The 10 members of the Noupagagnon VI group are all married women averaging 35 years of age, with three children, and living mostly in polygamous families in Tamba, a village in the commune of Nantien, Sikasso Prefecture, the third administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better manage their agricultural activities during the rainy season.

They are on their fifth loan with the institution, and their prior loans have been duly repaid.

They cultivate peanuts [ground nuts] and sweet peas, which is, for example, what Safiatou does (she is the first one standing on the right in the photo). With her loan, she plans to pay labor costs, buy agricultural inputs [fertilizers etc] and seeds in order to work a land plot of 0.5 ha [1.2 acres].

After harvesting, the produce is sold at the village and at the Sikasso market to a customer base composed of both men and women.

She plans to earn an average income of 30,000 West African Francs per agricultural season.

This income will allow her to repay her loan and help her husband provide for everyday household expenses. She would like to continue this collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso in order to cultivate her land better and derive a bigger income from it.

loans.use: to pay the costs of manual labor and buy seeds, fertilizers etc.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is 41 years of age and married. She has been blessed with four children. She manages a motorcycle transportation business. Her monthly net income is 3,000 Philippines pesos (PHP). She's asking for a loan of 6,000 PHP to pay for the repair and maintenance of her motorcycle. She hopes to one day open another business to increase her revenue and to continue borrowing from Kiva and ASKI so she can reach her business goal.

loans.use: to pay for the repair and maintenance of her motorcycle

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en:
Chizi is a married woman with two children, one who graduated from school and one who still attends. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past 10 years, she has operated a vegetable-stall business, selling at the market to neighbors and passersby. Major challenges she faces include seasonality and the high cost of transporting vegetables from rural areas to her place of operation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a grocery business in the future.

With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES), she wants to purchase bundles of green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes, and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes, and onions

loans.name: Analou

texts.en:
Analou is 30 years old and married. She has three children, ages 8, 6, and 1. She is a rice farmer working in the town of Sta. Josefa, Agusan del Sur. She has been growing and selling rice for six years.

Analou has requested a loan to purchase fertilizers and insecticides. She hopes this loan will help her achieve an abundant harvest. Analou also hopes for her family to be in good health always.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and insecticides

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en: Tabitha is a hardworking 36-year-old. She is married and blessed with three school-going children. She has been operating a retail shop for the last six years. She supplements her income through a taxi business and rental houses. Her dream is to own more rental houses. She wants a loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy more retail goods, such as maize flour, sugar, cooking fat, and salt.

loans.use: to buy retail goods, such as maize flour, sugar, cooking fat, and salt

loans.name: Janat

texts.en:
Janat is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children. All of her children are currently in school. Janat has a business of brick-laying, which she has had for over 10 years. She also has a second business of selling firewood.  

To help expand her business, Janat has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase firewood for burning the bricks and paying some of the workers. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Janat hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. 

In the future, Janat hopes to own a charcoal business. Janat is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save.

loans.use: to purchase firewood for burning bricks and to pay some of the workers

loans.name: Keom

texts.en:
Keom, 50, is a married rice farmer who lives in Kompong Speu Province. She is married to Mr. Chork, who is 51. They have three children, two of whom are single and one who is married. One of her children sells clothes in Phnom Penh City. 

Keom's husband has been earning a living for many years by climbing the palm trees behind his house. Palm-tree-climbing jobs are very common for poor people who live in the commune. Keom is looking for a loan to help her daughter buy more clothes for resale.

loans.use: to help her daughter buy more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs (such as fertilizers and seeds) and small equipment.

loans.name: Binti

texts.en:
Binti is a married woman with 7 children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past 10 years, she has operated a vegetable stall business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of establishing a food stall in the future.

With the 10,000 KES, she wants to purchase bundles of mangoes, cassavas and green vegetables. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of mangoes, cassavas and green vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs (such as fertilizers and seeds) and small equipment.

loans.name: Dominick

texts.en: Dominick is 39 years old, married, and has 3 children between 2 and 10 years old. Dominick has been running an electronic goods sales business for the last 3 years. He says that the business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. Dominick hopes to use his loan to further develop his electronic sales business. He hopes to transform his small business to a wholesaler. He also sees himself owning a plot of land on which he will build a house for his family. He describes himself as a visionary man.

loans.use: to purchase electronics

loans.name: Nazira's Group

texts.en:
Nazira is the leader of this group. She is 30 and married to a farmer. With her husband, she brings up two sons. The first son studies at school and the second son is preschool age (under seven). 

In order to earn money to meet their daily needs, the family breeds cattle and cultivates agricultural products. Nazira also sells milk every day to earn additional money. She applied for the loan because she needs additional financial funds for purchasing a washing machine. She wants to improve the family’s living conditions. In the future Nazira wants to give her children a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a washing machine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cloth materials for her tailoring business and sacks of green vegetables.

loans.name: Ayyob

texts.en:
Ayyob is a 28-year-old man who lives in Gaza City in Palestine. He is engaged and will get married this summer. Ayyob needs a loan of $2,500 to pay for his wedding expenses as he is having it this summer.  Ayyob is a Palestinian National Authority employee and gets a decent salary that doesn't cover all the expenses of preparing his house as well as wedding hall expenses. Getting FATEN's loan, which is repaid on a monthly basis, will be easier.

Ayyob is photographed in FATEN's office in Gaza.

loans.use: to pay for his wedding expenses

loans.name: Rimah

texts.en:
Rimah is a young woman from Maythalon village near Jenin city in Palestine. She is married and a mother of two daughters and four sons. Rimah took out a loan of $1,000 to purchase plowing tools. Her husband is a farmer and needs to prepare his land but the tools he has are not usable.anymore. Rimah's husband grows seasonal vegetables and wants to start growing fruits and increase the variety of crops he sells to shops in Maythalon.

Rimah is a conservative woman.Therefore. her husband is photographed in the picture.

loans.use: to purchase plowing tools

loans.name: Yesu Ammala Kamwokya Group

texts.en:
For 43 year old Eva, a resolute and steadfast business woman operating in Kamwokya, Kampala, success in any business undertaking is down to one's strong will, tenaciousness, hard work, proper planning, and prayers. This, combined with the conviction that one can succeed against every odd stacked against them, is of paramount importance. 

The happily married mother of 5  has shown, for the last 7 years, that one does not need to have prior business experience to lay a foundation for themselves in their business endeavors. She set forth in her business as a novice and, at present, she is regarded as a trail blazer who began her own spare parts business out of her own enterprise. Eva deals in all  car, bicycle and motorcycle spare parts. Her clientele are principally car drivers and commercial motorcycle riders. Weekly, she reckons her sales revenue totals up to shillings 100,000. Eva has a second business that she operates, the sale of plastic bottles. Eva says she is requesting for this kiva loan to purchase more spare parts to resell at her shop.

loans.use: to purchase of more spare parts to resell.

loans.name: Rodgers

texts.en:
Rodgers is a married man with five children, three boys and two girls. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past five years, he has operated a video show business, selling from home to his neighbours and passersby. He faces a major challenge of high cost of repairing machines which break down in his business. Rodgers dreams of establishing another business in the future.

With the KES 10,000 he wants to purchase a computer and a laminating machine. He decided to work with Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase a computer and a laminating machine.

loans.name: Afaf

texts.en:
Afaf is a 44-year-old woman who lives in Qalqilia city in Palestine, She has her own project to raise goats and produce dairy products that she sells in Qalqilia, Afaf came to FATEN and borrowed $800 to expand the project and purchase an extra two goats. Afaf started her project five years ago on her father's land. Her father is a farmer and grows olive trees. The loan Afaf took will allow her to increase production and gain more customers with her products.

Afaf is a conservative woman. Therefore, her father is photographed instead.

loans.use: to purchase two goats

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a married man with six children: four attend school while two are too young for school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, Ali has operated a retail shop business, selling to his neighbours and passersby. He also sells coconuts, which contributes to his other source of income. He faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation in his business. Ali dreams of expanding his business to a wholesale business in the future.

With the KES 10,000 he wants to purchase bundles of maize flour, wheat flour, beans and paraffin. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of maize flour, wheat flour, beans and paraffin.

loans.name: Mwahanje

texts.en:
Mwahanje is a married man with seven children. Four attend school while three are under age. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, he has operated a retail shop, selling to his neighbors and passersby. He faces a major challenge in the high cost of transporting goods from urban areas to his place of operation. He dreams of expanding his business in the future.

He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business. With the KES 10,000, he wants to purchase bundles of maize flour, sugar, wheat flour and cooking oil.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of maize flour, sugar, wheat flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a large variety of accessories to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase household items, sugar, maize flour and wheat flour.

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud, a young man from Ramallah city, is married and a father of two children. Mahmoud is an employee of the National Palestinian Authority Employees Affairs Division. He took a loan to pay for his car insurance, licensing and regular maintenance fees. Mahmoud, who is photographed here, is an employee with a decent salary and FATEN's loan will help him pay for the expenses mentioned above..

loans.use: To pay for car insurance, licensing and maintenance.

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina is a 52-year-old married woman living in the Philippines. She has three children. Carolina's spouse works as a driver in their community. 

Carolina is engaged in a business of raising chickens for sale and she offers dressed chickens too. She has been in the business for over 20 years and she earns approximately PHP 3,000 monthly.

Carolina is requesting for a loan of PHP 7,000. She plans to use this loan to have additional revolving capital to purchase feed for the chickens.

In the future, Carolina would like to strengthen her business in order to provide a better living for her family.

loans.use: to purchase feed for chickens.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Monica owns a posho mill machine used for grinding maize and millet into flour. Her potential customers are the neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of the machine breaking down and the unavailability of parts. Monica dreams of expanding her business in the future. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. 

With the KES 10,000 she wants to purchase fuel for her posho mill machine.

loans.use: To purchase fuel for her posho mill machine.

loans.name: Beaudelaire

texts.fr:
Client de 28 ans, célibataire sans enfant, après son bac , ne pouvant poursuivre ses etudes universitaires , il ouvre une cabine téléphonique  en 2007. Sa cabine téléphonique est a domicile , il a une forte clientèle , il a des recettes régulières de 40.000 a 70.000frs par jour.

Étant a son deuxième cycle de prêt,il va renforcer son activité en achetant des cartes de recharges de différents réseaux, cartes téléphoniques,cartes prépayés et des cartes SIM,il veut aussi s'abonner au réseau nationale a Congo Telecom pour pouvoir satisfaire les désirs de ses clients.

Il a une forte ambition , il veut a la longue une ouvrir plusieurs  cabines téléphoniques  et epargner beaucoup plus pour construire une petite agence et améliorer ses conditions de travail, être a l'abri de la pluie et du soleil.
texts.en:
He is a 28 year old client who is single with no children and was unable to continue his studies at university after obtaining his baccalaureate .In 2007 he opened a telephone booth which  is at his home, he has many customers and regular revenue of 40.000 to 70.000 Frs. per day.

This is his second loan, he intends to reinforce his activity by purchasing top up cards for different networks, telephone cards, prepaid cards and SIM cards. He also intends to subscribe to the Congo Telecom national network to satisfy his customers.

He is very ambitious, in the long term he aims to open several telephone booths and to save up to build a small agency to improve his working conditions and be sheltered from the rain and the sun.

loans.use: Purchase top up telephone cards, prepaid cards and SIM cards.

loans.name: Ulpatkan's Group

texts.en:
Ulpatkan is the leader of this group. She is 53 and married to a pensioner. Together with her husband she has raised eight children. The youngest son, 13, studies at school and the other children are either married or employed. The children try to support their parents financially, but Ulpatkan still needs money to meet the family needs. 

Together with her husband she cultivates agricultural products. Selling some part of the harvest she earns an additional 4,000 KGS per month. She applied for the loan because she needs additional funds to purchase mineral fertilizers. 

In the future Ulpatkan wants to see all her children married and employed.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Mbodze

texts.en:
Mbodze is a married woman with four children, one boy and three girls. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mbodze has operated a retail shop for the past year, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. In addition she also sells dried fish for another source of income. 

She faces a major challenge of seasonality since during rainy season customers are few. She dreams of establishing a wholesale business in the future.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat and maize flour and sacks of dried fish. She decided to work with Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat and maize flour and sacks of dried fish.

loans.name: Laila

texts.en:
Laila is a 44-year-old woman and a mother of six children. She owns a grocery store. She wants a loan of $3,000 to have a better income by increasing the variety of items she sells as grocery stores are in big numbers in the area where she lives. Laila's store is on a big shopping street and has a good chance of increasing the number of customers. Laila came to FATEN to take out the needed loan.

Laila is a conservative woman. Therefore, her husband is photographed instead in the store.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell in the store

loans.name: Ng'anzuki

texts.en:
Ng'anzuki is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a family house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past six years, she has operated a maize selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality and high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of expanding and opening another business in the future.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of maize for sale and establish a maize selling stall. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of maize for sale and establish a maize selling stall.

loans.name: Cholpon's Group

texts.en:
Cholpon is the leader of this group. She is 41 and divorced. She is bringing up three daughters. The oldest daughter studies at university and the others are at school. 

Cholpon used to work in the hospital. She saved some money and purchased livestock. She started to breed livestock a year ago with an initial investment of 10,000 KGS. Reselling livestock after fattening, Cholpon earns 5,000 KGS per month. 

She applied for the loan because she needs additional funds to increase the number of livestock. In the future, with the profits gained from the business, Cholpon plans to purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Gela

texts.en:
Gela is a 32-year-old farmer from the village Kedkedi in the mountainous Adjara region. He is married and lives with his wife, Kristine, two daughters (3 and 2 years old) and parents. All adult family members are involved in the family agricultural activities, which are the main source of income for the family. 

Gela’s family owns a hectare land where various citrus fruits and vegetables are grown. They sell the harvested products to local retailers. They also have a milk cow whose milk is used for cheese production. They sell the cheese in the village. Also, Gela runs small bee-keeping farm. He has 25 beehives with bee colonies. He sells the honey locally in the village. The total average monthly income of the family is 614 GEL. 

With the requested credit Gela will purchase an additional four or five beehives and bee colonies. He will get and sell more honey and the income of the family will increase, allowing the family members to purchase more and better goods and services.

loans.use: to purchase additional beehives and bee colonies.

loans.name: Bessik

texts.en:
Bessik comes from the village of Tkhilnari in the mountainous Adjara region. He is 25 years old and married. Bessik lives with his wife and parents. He is the only provider of income for the whole family.

Bessik drives a mini bus in the Adjara region. Along with this job, he leads the agricultural activities of the family. They own 0.3 hectare of the land where they grow citrus and other fruits. They sell the harvested products on the local market. 

Also, the family has a small poultry farm. Bessik purchases chickens and after they are grown, he sells them on the local market. His wife and mother always help Bessik on the farm. The total average monthly income of the family is 1,350 GEL, including the health pension for Bessik’s father. 

With the requested credit, Bessik plans to purchase more chickens for the farm. As a result of the credit, he will be able to sell more poultry and increase the income of the family. Bessik plans to use the increased income to purchase new household items to make the house more comfortable.

loans.use: to purchase chickens for the poultry farm.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is a single woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

For the past three years, she has operated a poultry business, selling from home to butcher operators and restaurant operators. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation and the high cost of chicken feed. She dreams of expanding her chicken house to accommodate lots of chickens in the future. 

With the KES 80,000, she wants to purchase chicken feed and more chicks. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase chicken feed and more chicks.

loans.name: Tamaraneh Traders Assoc. Group

texts.en:
Margrette was born in Makeni about 37 years ago. She is married with three children, two in primary school and one in secondary school. Margrette is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs.

Margrette sells jeans, sneakers, t-shirts, portmanteaux (large suitcases), etc. She has been in business for five years now.

Margrette will use her share of the loan (1,500,000 SLL) to buy the above-mentioned items in large quantities for her business. With the help of this loan, she and her group member will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to buy clothes in large quantities for her business.

loans.name: Tiburce

texts.fr:
Client de 33, marie et père de 2 enfants dont l'age varie entre 1 et 6 ans. A la fin de ses etudes universitaires, il ouvre une petite alimentation devant sa parcelle, ou il vend des boites de conserves, des sucreries, des savons, des biscuits, ses recettes régulières sont de 10.000 a 20.000 fr par jour.

Avec le pret recu il va renforcer son stock en  achetant 10 cartons de savons de toilette et savons a linge,5 cartons  des boites de conserves comme la sardine, corne bœuf, macédoine, 10 cartons de spaghetti,2 cartons de macaronis,il s'approvisionne dans les grands magasins de la ville et parfois il fait des commandes a Kinshasa.

Il a pour ambition d'ouvrir une grande boutique,vendre plus pour qu'avec le temps et epargner pour qu'a la longue qu'il soit grossiste.
texts.en:
This 33 year old client  is married with two children between the ages of 1 and 6.At the end of his university studies, he opened a small grocery in front of his plot of land, where he sells tins of aliments, sweets, soap and biscuits, his  regular takings  are of 10.000 to  20.000 Frs. per day.

With this loan he intends to stock up on goods by purchasing 10 boxes of body soap and laundry soap, 5 boxes of tins such as sardines, corned beef, mixed vegetables, 10 boxes of spaghetti and 2 boxes of macaroni. He buys his stock in the big shops in town and sometimes he places orders in Kinshasa.

He aims to open a big shop and sell more so that in time he can save up and become a wholesaler.

loans.use: purchase boxes of biscuits, sweets, soap, tinned food.

loans.name: Suraie

texts.ru: Сурайё проживает в районе Шахринав. Она замужем. У неё двое детей. Она имеет среднее образование. Более десяти лет Сайёра работает в кафе помошником повара. Она кредит берет для покупки продуктов и новой посуды для кафе.
texts.en: Suraie lives in Shahrinav.  She is married and has two children.  She has a secondary education.   For more than ten years, Suraie has been working in a cafe assisting the cooks.  She is taking out a loan to buy foodstuffs and new dishes for the cafe.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs and new dishes.

loans.name: Kupha

texts.en:
Kupha is a married woman with seven children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past four years Kupha has operated a retail shop, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During holiday season is when she gets lots of customers purchasing kanga's. 

Kupha decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With a 40,000 KES loan she wants to purchase bundles of lesso's (kanga's) and cloth material to start another business of selling clothes. Kupha dreams of expanding and establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: To start a clothes selling business, purchase bundles of lesso's (kanga's) and cloth materials to sell.

loans.name: Las Emprendedoras Group

texts.es:
El comité “Las Emprendedoras” se formó gracias al deseo D. mejoramiento y superacíon del nivel D. vida D. las integrantes ya que son personas D. muy escasos recursos, ellas con su esfuerzo diario tratan D. aumentar los ingresos y mejorar su forma D. vida.
Ellas se definen como mujeres muy responsable y luchadoras, tienen un deseo que es el poder brindar a sus familias lo mejor, es decir todo aquello a lo que no tuvieron acceso.
La Sra. Esmilce se dedica a la venta D. comestibles desD. hace ya varios años, ella tiene una clientela bien definida.Ella trabaja todos los días desD. muy tempranas horas, prepara los comestibles y luego los venD..
Ella solicita el credito para la compra D. los insumos para la elaboración D. sus alimentos, como ser, carne, huevo, embutidos, hortalizas y demás.
texts.en:
The “Las Emprendedoras” committee was formed thanks to the desire that the members had to improve themselves and their quality of life as they are people with very limited financial resources.  Through their daily efforts, they try to increase their income and improve their way of life.

The members of this group describe themselves as very responsible and tenacious women who have a desire to proviD. their families with the best, that is to say, everything that they did not have themselves.

Esmilce has been selling food for several years.  She has a well-defined customer base.  She works every day, from very early in the morning, preparing her food and then selling it.

Esmilce is requesting a loan to buy supplies for making her food such as meat, eggs, cold meats, vegetables, etc.

loans.use: to buy meat, vegetables, eggs, etc. for her business making food

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy jeans, t-shirts, sneakers, etc. in bulk to add to his stock.

loans.name: Inobat

texts.ru: Инобат проживает в городе Душанбе. Она разведена. У неё один маленький ребенок. Она имеет среднее образование. Более двух лет Инобат арендует салон и занимается услугой парикмахера. Кредит берет для покупки настенного зеркала и кресло для салона красоты.
texts.en: Inobat lives in Dushanbe.  She is divorced and has one small child.  She has a secondary education.  For more than two years, Inobat has rented a salon and worked as a beautician.  She is taking out a loan to buy a wall mirror and a chair to decorate the salon.

loans.use: to buy a wall mirror and a chair

loans.name: Bertrand Renaud

texts.fr:
Client de 32 ans, marie et père d'un enfant de 6 mois,a la fin de la guerre qu'a connu le Congo, il ouvre une petite alimentation pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Des le matin , il a des recettes de 10.000 a 30.000 fr par jour, ses clients potentiels sont ses voisins et passants de son quartier.

A l'octroi de son pret , il va acheter des  5 cartons de bougies , 5 cartons de conserves,5 cartons de spaguetti, et tous le necessaire dont les clients ont besoin, il s'approvisionne dans les grands dépôts de la place.

Tres entreprenant, il a des stratégies de vente très efficaces , baisser les prix ,récompenser les 5 premiers clients de la journée.
A l'avenir il veut devenir grossiste et construire un grand magasin.
texts.en:
This borrower is 32 years old, married, and the father of a 6-month-old child. At the end of the war in Congo, he opened a small grocery shop to support his family. His revenues average 10,000 to 30,000 francs per day. Potential clients include neighbors and passersby from the area.

He will use this loan to buy 5 boxes of candles, 5 boxes of canned goods, 5 boxes of spaghetti, and anything his customers may need. He buys his merchandise from the main depots of the locality.

He is very enterprising, and has effective sales strategies such as lowering prices, and rewarding the first 5 customers of the day.

In the future, he wants to become a wholesaler and build a large store.

loans.use: to buy boxes of cookies, bags of sugar, boxes of soap, canned goods, powder detergent, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more bags of cement to use in putting up new rental structures.

loans.name: Farhod

texts.ru: Фарход проживает в Гиссарском районе. Женат. Детей не имеет. У него среднее образование. Более шести лет Фарход торгует в магазине. Кредит берет для расширения бизнеса, закупа арбузов и дынь.
texts.en: Farhod lives in the Gissar region.  He is married but has no children.  He has a secondary education.  He has worked in sales in a shop for more than six years.  He is taking out a loan to expand his business by buying watermelons and other melons.

loans.use: to buy watermelons and other melons.

loans.name: Jeremiah

texts.en:
Jeremiah is a hard working 34 year old business man.  He is married and blessed with three children ages: 9, 6 and 3.  He has been buying and re-selling scrap metal for the last 4 years.  He supplements his income by rearing bulls for sale.  Previously he used to cultivate crops. 

He wants in the next 5 years to own 5 dairy cows so that he is able to realize his dream of being a dairy farmer.  He wants a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy scrap metal for resale.  Thanks to Faulu Kenya he has learned how to save.  On his bicycle, Jeremiah is carrying a sack of scrap metals.

loans.use: to buy scrap metal for resale

loans.name: Marinette

texts.fr:
Cliente de 39 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants dont l'age varie entre 10 et 16 ans, en 1998,  quand elle a eu son premier enfant, elle se lance dans la petite pâtisserie pour pouvoir venir en aide a son mari et a sa famille. Elle commence la fabrication de ses beignets de bon matin,ses potentiels clients sont la majorité des élèves et collégiens  qui  vont de bon matin a l'école primaire situe non loin de sa maison.
Elle vend en moyenne 8000 a 15.000 fr par jour.

A l'octroi se ce prêt , elle va acheter 50kg d farine, 50 kg de sucre, 5kg de margarine, 25kg de lait en poudre, 50kg de riz pour préparer la bouillie du riz au lait.

Ayant deja une grande maitrise dans l'exercice de son activité, elle épargne pour qu'a la longue, elle aide son mari a construire une maison pour ses enfants.
texts.en:
This customer is 39 years old, married and a mother of four children aged 10 to 16. In 1998, after having her first child, she launched her small pastry business to be able to help her husband and family. She starts preparing her fritters early in the morning, her potential customers mostly being the elementary and middle school students who go to the primary school located near her house. Her daily sales are generally between 8,000 and 15,000 XAF.
With this loan, she will purchase 50 kilos of flour, 50 kilos of sugar, 5 kilos of margarine, 25 kilos of powdered milk and 50 kilos of rice to prepare rice porridge with milk.
She is already quite experienced in running her business and is saving for the long-term, to help her husband build a house for her children.

loans.use: to buy 50-kilo bags of flour and sugar, 25 kilos of milk, a 5-kilo jar of margarine and baking powder.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a large quantity of baby clothes to add to her current ones

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 38 years old.  She is married and blessed with four children ages: 15, 11, 7 and 4.  She has been selling second hand clothes for the last two years.  She supplements her income by selling grocery.  Previously she used to run a retail shop.

In the next 5 years she wants to be financially stable.  She wants a loan of 9,000 Kenya shillings to buy a solar lamp for use in her home in the place of electricity.  Thanks to Faulu Kenya she has been able to make her business do well and thus she is able to cater for the needs of those who depend on her better than before.

loans.use: to buy a solar lamp

loans.name: Believe In God Group

texts.en:
Mariatu is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs.  Mariatu was born in one of the villages that make up Sanda, a few miles from Makeni city.  She is a 30-year-old.  Mariatu is married and has 4 children who are attending primary school. 

Mariatu has been a businesswoman for 9 years now.  She sells clothes – t-shirts, jeans, bed sheets, towels, etc.  Mariatu and members of her group have applied for a loan of SLL 1,2000,000 for each of them from Kiva lenders in order to further boost their respective businesses.  Mariatu is going to use her share of the loan to buy clothes in bulk to add to her business.

loans.use: to buy clothes – t-shirts, jeans, bed sheets, towels, etc. in bulk to add to her business

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 41 years old, married and has three children.  

She runs a grocery store to earn a living. She has been in the business for three years. She has managed to retain her business because she has been trained on business management skills.

Margaret hopes to buy a piece of land in the future. She has requested 10,000 KES to buy vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To buy vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 40 years old. She is married and blessed with six children who are school going. Their ages are 20, 18, 15, 13, 6 and 2. 

She has been doing small-scale farming for the last three and a half years. She supplements her income by raising poultry. Previously, she used to engage in dairy farming. 

In the next five years she wants to increase her customer base so that she is able to make enough capital to be financially stable.

She wants a loan of 9,000 KES to buy an environmentally friendly solar lamp to supplement electricity. Thanks to Faulu Kenya she has become self-dependent.

loans.use: to buy a solar lamp.

loans.name: La Union Group

texts.es:
El comité denominado La Unión, es de la ciudad de Asunción, está integrado por 18 mujeres. Todas ellas son vecinas y amigas de esa ciudad. Ellas se juntaron al escuchar hablar del programa de mujeres emprendedoras y quedaron encantadas con la idea.
Ellas trabajan en un ambiente de cooperación y respeto. Luchan por un fin en común, que es el de proveer a sus hijos un mejor futuro, y mayores ingresos, para poder tener una vida digna y decorosa.
La Sra. Isidora se dedica a la venta de hortalizas. Ella por medio de este trabajo ha podido sacar adelante a toda su familia, también ha logrado mantenerse a ella misma y a su familia. Ella tiene el sueño de poder abrir, algún día, un pequeño local donde ofrecer sus hortalizas.
Ella solicita el credito para la compra de mas hortalizas que podrá vender. Tiene las esperanzas puestas en el credito ya que le sera de gran ayuda.
texts.en:
This committee is called 'La Unión' and it is located in the city of Asunción.  It has 18 members (all of whom are women).  They are all neighbors and friends who live in this city.  They came together to listen to somebody explain about the 'Entrepreneurial Women's Program' and were very taken with the idea.

The women work in an environment of cooperation and respect.  They work together towards a common goal which is providing their children with a better future and making more income so that they can lead a decent life.

Isidora's business is selling vegetables.  Through this work, she has been able to get her whole family ahead in life.  She has managed to support herself and her family.  Her dream is to some day open small business premises from which she can sell her vegetables.

Isidora is requesting a loan to buy more vegetables to sell.  She has her hopes placed in this loan as it will be very helpful to her.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to sell such as tomatoes, lettuce, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more timber to make more wooden chairs, windows, tables and side boards to resell.

loans.name: Ayigul

texts.en:
Ayigul lives in the north of Kyrgyzstan. She is 46 years old, widowed and has three grown-up children. She worked for a long time as a cook in the local area. 

19 years ago, in order to support her family, Ayigul began her business of cattle breeding and farming. She rented land near Namatbek village, where her family started to cultivate potatoes and beans. In addition, she gained a good income from selling milk products at the local market through breeding milk cows. Thanks to persistent work, her business expanded but still needs to develop. For this reason, Ayigul plans to use the loan of 40,000 KGS to purchase fertilizers for her land. With the revenue from this investment, Ayigul plans to buy a truck in order to transport milk products and potatoes to the markets in her region.  

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a solar lamp

loans.name: Giorgi

texts.en:
Giorgi, from the village of Kveda Simoneti, Terjola district, is a musician who sings in a local restaurant during the evening hours. He lives with his adult children: a 21-year-old daughter and a 20-year-old son and daughter-in-law.

Along with his main job, Giorgi is also actively involved in the family farming business which includes four milk cows and two calves. Giorgi sells approximately 800 liters of milk in the nearby town of Kutaisi.The family also has a six-hectare plot of the land upon which maize is grown. Harvested corn is used on the dairy farm to feed the livestock.

Giorgi is requesting a loan for the construction of a cattle shed, as the old one is too small for the existing livestock and won't accommodate any increase in the family's number of cows or calves. In the future, Giorgi plans to expand the farming activities by purchasing additional milk cows.

loans.use: to purchase materials for cattle-shed construction.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy maize flour, cooking fat, salt and sugar.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a solar lamp

loans.name: Anara

texts.en:
Anara is 40, married and has three children. She works as an accountant for the local administration and also cultivates her land. Her family has been farming for the past 15 years, starting with initial capital of 7,000 Kyrgyz soms (KGS). They work hard on 1.67 hectares of irrigated land growing beans and potatoes. 

Now Anara is applying for a loan of 25,000 KGS to buy manure to fertilize the land. With the revenue, she plans to broaden her business by getting involved in cattle breeding. 

======================================

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target an especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 38 years old. She is married and blessed with two children aged 12 and 7. She has been running a retail shop for the last 4 years. In the next 5 years she wants to open up several outlets so that she will be able to venture into other counties for business.

She wants a loan of 9,000 Kenyan shillings to buy an environmentally friendly solar lamp. Thanks to Faulu Kenya she has become more self-reliant.

loans.use: to buy an environmentally friendly solar lamp

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To build a zero-grazing unit and buy a chuff cutter.

loans.name: Zarbubu

texts.en:
Zarbubu is a very good-natured woman. She is 53, married and has five children. She lives in Zhany-Korgon village in the south of Kyrgyzstan and is engaged in cattle breeding and land cultivating. She started with initial capital of 10,000 soms (KGS) which was used to purchase a heifer. Being a persistent person, Zarbubu works hard to enlarge her business and achieve success – today she has two milk cows and a calf. 

Zarbubu plans to use this loan of 60,000 KGS to expand her herd and purchase mineral fertilizers that will lead to an increased harvest and top quality products. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target an especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase pigs, sheep and guinea pigs.

loans.name: Pazilet

texts.en:
Pazilet is 50, widowed, and has one daughter. She works as a nurse at the local hospital. In order to support her family, three years ago she began a cattle breeding business. Currently, she has three milk cows at her farm. She sells milk to local customers and makes a monthly profit of 5,000 soms (KGS). 

Pazilet plans to use this loan of 80,000 KGS to purchase two cows. With the revenue, she plans to pay for a good education for her daughter. In the future, Pazilet plans to broaden her business activities. 

======================================

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target an especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en:
Solomon is 40 years old, married and has a nine-year-old child. For five years he has been operating a butchery. He also has a dairy to supplement his income.

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has improved his business, thus raising his standard of living. He is requesting 30,000 KES to buy two cows for slaughter.

Solomon hopes to become financially stable in the future. His dream is to own a slaughterhouse in five years.

loans.use: To buy two cows for slaughter.

loans.name: Kamiyat's Group

texts.en:
Kamiyat is 22 years old, married and has two children, all of whom are currently in school. She lives in the town of Kyengera in the central region of Kampala in Uganda.

Kamiyat sells snacks, which she has done for six years. Kamiyat is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her capital.

To help expand her business, Kamiyat has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase ground nuts to fry and sell.

With the help of the loan from BRAC, Kamiyat hopes to generate greater profits and pay the school fees for her children. In the future, Kamiyat hopes to own a production business.

loans.use: to purchase ground nuts to fry and sell.

loans.name: Kubanichbek

texts.en:
Kubanichbek is 31 years old, married, and has three children. He lives with his family in Echki-Bashy village. He graduated from State University and works as a trainer at the local school.

Unfortunately, the salaries of teachers in rural areas are very low and do not cover all household expenses. To create another source of income, in 2001 Kubanichbek started breeding cattle. With initial capital of 25,000 KGS, he bought cattle and managed to enlarge their number. Today he has an income of 8,000 KGS a month.

Now Kubanichbek is requesting a loan of 50,000 KGS to buy more cattle. With the revenues from this loan, Kubanichbek plans to expand his livestock operation.

loans.use: to buy more cattle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a chaff cutter.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 47 years old, married and has three children. He is able to educate his children with the income from his business.

For the past sixteen years he has been selling second-hand shoes to earn a living. He has employed one person to assist him in the business.

Peter has benefited from Faulu Kenya because he has learned how to save his money. He has requested an 80,000 KES loan to move to a bigger and better business site. With his profits he hopes to grow his business.

loans.use: to move to a bigger and better business site.

loans.name: Las Catalinas Group

texts.es: Este grupo se llama "Las Catalinas", está ubicado en el estado de Morelos, en México. El grupo está conformado por 9 integrantes y es la primera vez que solicitan un prestamo. Martha es integrante del grupo, es casada,  tiene 42 años, es comerciante, tiene un total de 4 hijos 3 mujeres y un varón, ella se dedica a la venta de  Ropa negocio que inicio hace 25 años, cuenta con un local propio donde exhibe su mercancía y además puede ofrecer otros artículos según la temporada, solicita el préstamo para comprar mercancía ya que viene la temporada de comprar uniforme nuevo para los estudiantes ya que comienzan un nuevo ciclo escolar, ella quiere comprar ropa como calcetines, camisetas y accesorios que utilizan los estudiantes para este regreso a clases, sus clientes la prefieren porque cuenta con una gran variedad de diseños. Con las ganancias ella quiere ahorrar para la educación de sus hijos y apoyar en los gastos de la casa.
texts.en: This group is called "Las Catalinas" and is located in the Morelos state, in Mexico. The group is made up of 9 members, and this is the first time that they are requesting a loan. Martha is a member of the group. She is married, 42, and a businesswoman. She has a total of 4 children; 3 girls and one boy. She sells clothing, a business that she started 25 years ago. She has her own storefront where she displays her merchandise, and she is able to offer other articles seasonally. She is requesting a loan for the purchase of merchandise, since the season for buying new school uniforms is approaching; a new school year is about to begin. She wants to purchase clothing such as socks, shirts and accessories which the students use for the return to school. Her customers prefer her business because she has a large variety of designs. With her income, she wants to save up for her children's education, and to help out with the household costs.

loans.use: to purchase clothing suck as socks, shirts and accessories

loans.name: Utamaduni Group

texts.en:
Melisiana, who is in her mid-forties, is married with three children who go to school. She has been selling fruits and vegetables for six years now. She works from 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Melisiana’s fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to pay school fees and increase the amount of produce she sells. She paid back all of her loans successfully.

Melisiana hopes for a loan for household expenses and to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell. She will share this 4,510,000 TZS loan with her loan group, "Utamaduni," which has a total of fifteen members who will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

Melisiana’s dream is to one day finish building her house which she has already started.

loans.use: to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell and for household expenses.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a married man with five children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. His greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past five years, David has operated a shop, selling to his neighbors and passersby. In addition, he also sells water, which contributes additional income. David faces a major challenge in the high cost of transportation in his business.

David decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business. With a 20,000 KES loan he wants to purchase water pipes for a water distribution business. His dream is to purchase a water tank in the future.

loans.use: to purchase water pipes for a water distribution business.

loans.name: Mitsubishi Group

texts.en:
Iman, who is in his early 20s, is single. He takes care of his brother's son who is about 3 years old.

He has been running two businesses. He has a barber shop and he has had a bajaji (tricycle) for three years. He works from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily and is able to earn a fair monthly profit.

This will be his third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to expand and repaint his barber shop, take driving lessons and pay household expenses, and he has paid back all his loans successfully. 

He hopes for a loan to buy more salon equipment to attract customers. His dream is to one day build his own house.

He will share this loan with his loan group, "Mitsubishi," which has 15 members who will hold each other accountable in repaying their loans.

loans.use: To buy more salon equipment to attract customers.

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Group

texts.es:
El comité Mujeres Unidas se conformó en la ciudad de Pilar, con mucho esfuerzo de todas las miembros, ellas  ya se encuentran en el 6 ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa.
Además del trabajo independiente de cada una, también desarrollan actividades en forma conjunta, a la vez se ayudan mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos que es la de trabajar para apoyar a sus familias. 
La de la Sra. Francisca quien se dedica a la venta de ropa, desde ya hace muchos años, por medio de este trabajo ha podido salir adelante y la economía de la familia mejoró ya que ella mantiene la casa.
Ella solicita el credito para la compra de mas ropas, con lo cual podrá atraer a mas clientes. Ella sabe que el credito le sera de gran ayuda en su pequeño negocio.
texts.en:
The Mujeres Unidas ["United Women"] group was formed in the city of Pilar, with a great deal of work from all of the members. They are now in their sixth cycle, working together within the program.
On top of each woman's independent work, they also do group activities. Currently, they are helping each other to achieve their objectives, which are to work in order to support their families.
Mrs. Francisca, who has sold clothing for many years, has been able to get ahead through this work. Her family's economic situation has improved and she is able to maintain her household.
She is requesting this loan for the purchase of more clothing, with which she will be able to attract more customers. She knows that his loan will be a great help to her little business.

loans.use: to purchase clothing for the next sale.

loans.name: Yvette Nathalie

texts.fr:
Cliente de 35 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfant dont l'age varie entre 6 et 15 ans.A l'arrêt de ses etudes en classe de 4eme par manque de soutien financier , elle se lance dans la vente du mais en gros et détail, elle a une forte clientèle et ses ventes sont de 10.000 a 30.000frs par jour. 

Elle s'approvisionne a la gare ferroviaire , a l'octroi de son prêt elle  va renforcer son stock en achetant 10 sacs de 50 kg de mais , qu'elle va vendre chez les éleveurs de poules et et les femmes qui préparent la farine de mais.

Pour l'avenir elle pense ouvrir un dépôt de vente en gros  de sacs de mais et aller elle même  s'approvisionner  dans les villages environnant auprès des cultivateurs.
texts.en:
This borrower is 35 years old and married with three children ranging from 6 to 15 years old. Having quit school in the 4th grade for lack of financial support, she started selling maize at retail and wholesale. She has a strong customer base and her sales average 10,000 to 30,000 francs per day. She buys her stock at the train station. 

She will use her loan to increase her stock by buying ten 50 kg bags of maize, which she will sell to chicken farmers and to women who make maize flour.

In the future, she would like to open a depot to sell sacks of maize wholesale. She also wants to personally travel to neighboring villages to buy maize from the growers

loans.use: to buy ten 50kg bags of maize

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.es: Beatriz tiene 46 años de edad casado con Adrian de 48 años, juntos tienen un hijo quien estudia en la universidad. Ellos viven en su casa propia ubicada en la localidad de puerto mayo jurisdicción del distrito de Pichari. Desde muy joven Beatriz  se dedicó a la actividad agrícola, específicamente al cultivo del cacao, pero cuando llegó el momento de formalizar  su familia, con ayuda económica de su esposo lograron adquirir  un pequeño terreno en donde cultivaron cacao y café. Al pasar los años tuvieron a su hijo Joel, por quien su querido padre tuvo que sacrificarse mucho mientras que Beatriz aún no podía acompañarlo, solo se quedaba con los quehaceres de la casa. A medida que su hijo iba creciendo, ella ya podía trabajar y apoyar a su esposo en las labores agrícolas. Por tal razón desea abrir una tienda en donde pueda vender prendas de vestir. Este será su segundo crédito con MFP por lo que espera el apoyo de cada uno de ustedes para que pueda concretar sus objetivos. Por otro lado se compromete a ser puntual en el pago de sus cuotas.
